heat_fire.patient_friendly: Pain that feels like intense burning, radiating heat, or a sensation of fire inside the body.
heat_fire.likely_mechanism: Neurogenic inflammation or sensitization of peripheral nerves causing thermal hyperalgesia.
heat_fire.literature_framing: Patients with endometriosis often describe a burning or fire-like pain, associated with nociplastic pain and inflammatory cytokines (Fraser et al., 2018; Taylor et al., 2020).

electric_force.patient_friendly: Pain that feels like electric shocks, jolts, or zapping currents shooting through the body.
electric_force.likely_mechanism: Abnormal nerve firing or central sensitization leading to paroxysmal neuropathic discharges.
electric_force.literature_framing: Electric-like sensations may be indicative of nerve involvement in endometriosis, including referred neuropathic pain (Stratton & Berkley, 2011; As-Sanie et al., 2019).

pressure_weight.patient_friendly: Pain that feels like heaviness, compression, or being weighed down in the pelvic area.
pressure_weight.likely_mechanism: Pelvic congestion, inflammation, or mass effect from lesions or adhesions.
pressure_weight.literature_framing: Feelings of pressure or heaviness may align with reports of pelvic congestion and visceral sensitivity (Giudice & Kao, 2004; Vercellini et al., 2014).

violent_action.patient_friendly: Pain described as stabbing, cutting, punching, or being physically attacked from inside.
violent_action.likely_mechanism: Peripheral nerve activation due to inflammation or mechanical damage to pelvic structures.
violent_action.literature_framing: Descriptions of violent, sharp internal pain often reflect acute nociceptive pain associated with active endometrial lesions (Bullo et al., 2021; Zondervan et al., 2018).

mechanical.patient_friendly: Pain that feels like grinding, screeching, or mechanical friction in the pelvis.
mechanical.likely_mechanism: Adhesions or fibrosis restricting organ movement or causing tissue traction.
mechanical.literature_framing: Grinding or gear-like sensations may reflect mechanical strain caused by adhesions or fibrotic changes (Nezhat et al., 2012).

natural_force.patient_friendly: Pain that feels like storms, waves, earthquakes, or tsunamis moving inside the body.
natural_force.likely_mechanism: Systemic dysregulation of pain pathways, hormonal surges, and muscle contractions.
natural_force.literature_framing: Natural disaster metaphors are linked to patients' perceptions of unpredictability and uncontrollability of symptoms (Bullo, 2020).

foreign_object.patient_friendly: Pain that feels like something sharp or foreign is inside, like knives or glass.
foreign_object.likely_mechanism: Lesions or adhesions causing tissue penetration, inflammation, or nerve irritation.
foreign_object.literature_framing: Foreign object imagery correlates with descriptions of invasive pain from nodules or deep endometriosis (Chapron et al., 2019).

monster.patient_friendly: Pain that feels like a lurking or attacking creature inside, waiting to strike.
monster.likely_mechanism: Chronic illness perception and emotional distress shaping pain experience.
monster.literature_framing: Monster metaphors often embody fear and unpredictability, reinforcing the emotional impact of living with endometriosis (Bullo, 2020; Frank, 2013).

journey.patient_friendly: Pain described as being trapped, lost, or stuck on an endless path with no resolution.
journey.likely_mechanism: Psychological impact of diagnostic delay and chronicity on pain processing.
journey.literature_framing: Journey metaphors express the protracted, uncertain medical experience common among endometriosis patients (Ballweg, 2004; Denny, 2009).

other.patient_friendly: Pain that feels indescribable, strange, or like something is wrong but hard to explain.
other.likely_mechanism: Mixed pain signals, emotional distress, or underarticulated sensory experience.
other.literature_framing: Vague or ineffable pain descriptions often highlight language limits and the isolating experience of invisible illness (Scarry, 1985).
